coredata.dc:title: X-ray Ca K edge of calcium adenosine triphosphate system and of simple Ca compunds
coredata.dc:creator: Bianconi, A.
Doniach, S.
Lublin, D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Using synchrotron radiation the X-ray Ca K-absorption edges have been measured with high resolution. The Ca binding site in the adenosine triphosphate (ATP) has been studied. The K edges of simple Ca model compounds CaHPO3, CaCO3, and Ca(C2H3O2)2 have been measured, for comparison with the K edge of CaATP. The calcium site in ATP is similar to Ca site in calcium hydrogen phosphate.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 59, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 November 1978 X-RAY Ca K EDGE OF CALCIUM ADENOSINE TRIPHOSPHATE SYSTEM AND OF SIMPLE Ca COMPOUNDS* A. BIANCONI**, S. DONIACH and D. LUBLIN Department of Applied Physics and Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University. Stanford. California 94305. USA Received 24 July 1978 Using synchrotron radiation the X-ray Ca K-absorption edges have been measured with high resolution. The Ca binding site in the adencsine triphosphate (ATP) has been studied- The K edges of simple Ca model compounds CaHPOa, CaCOs, and Ca(C2H302)2 have been measured, for comparison with the K edge ofCaATP. The calcium site in ATP is similar to Ca site in calcium hydrogen phosphate- Calcium fulfils a great variety of biological functions. Calcium is an integral part of biological membranes and there are several calcium binding proteins [1]. Calcium binds also to non-protein anionic constituents of cells such as phospholipids and adenosine triphos- phate (ATP). The adenosine triphosphate, present in biological systems as an energy-transfer agent, is generally associated with divalent ions such as Ca2"'' or Mg2"1" [2]. The formation ofCaATP complex would be expected to control the free metal ion activity in cell fluids. Moreover the CaATP complexes appear to be the actual substrate in ATPase reactions [3]. (The Ca^ATPase accomplishes the transport of extra cellular calcium necessary for muscle contraction mechanism [4].) Few experiments have been made from the point of view of determining the metal ion binding site in the ATP molecule [5] and measuring the formation constant of the CaATP complex [6]. Recently syn- chrotron radiation spectroscopy in the X-ray range has been shown to be a powerful tool to study local structures- In this letter we report the measurement • All of the materials incorporated in this work were devel- oped with the financial support of the National Science Foundation under Contract DMR7727489 (in cooperation with the Department of Energy). •• Present address: Isrituto di Fisica. Universita di Camerino, 62032 Camerino, Italy; also at "P.U.L.S." Laboratori NazionaU di Frascati, Frascati, Italy. of the Ca K edge of CaATP and of several model com- pounds to determine the Ca binding site. The X-ray absorption spectra far above the absorption threshold contain information on the local structure around the absorbing atom such as the interatomic distance. In fact the matrix element of the inner-shell transitions in this energy range is modulated by final state interference effects (EXAFS) [7]. The detailed absorption structure observed within a few electron volts of a core level threshold is specific to the atomic environment surrounding the absorbing atom [8]. Due to the localization of the initial state, the inner-shell photoabsorption cross section is probing the local character of the final state. Near the absorp- tion edge the actual final state wavefunction is determined by the local molecular potential both in the continuum and in the discrete part of the spectrum. The excited states can be assigned to inner and outer-well excitations [8,9] and shape resonances [10] as it has been shown in simple molecules [11, 12]. The detailed interpretation of the spectrum requires the actual calculation of the final state wave- functions. The multiple scattering method [10] has succeeded in several cases [10,13,14] to reproduce and reveal the cause of resonance features in inner- shell spectra near the K threshold. An experimental approach to determine the site of an atom in a large complex molecule is to compare the K-edge absorp- tion spectrum of the selected atom with the K-edge of the same atom in simple chemical compounds where 121 Volume 59, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I November 1978 it is expected to occupy a similar site. Since the K- spectrum is sensitive only to the local structure, if the ate symmetry and the nature of the atoms surround- ing the absorbing atom are similar in the unknown chemical compound and in the known simple com- pound, the K spectra should be similar. We have used this approach to study the Ca site in CaATP complex. The present measurements have been made using synchrotron radiation X-rays on beam line II at Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory. A Si(l 11) channel-cut crystal monochromator, about 10 m from the point source in the storage ring SPEAR, has been used. The high intensity and the stability of the monochromatic X-ray beam allow exceptional high resolution and high signal to noise ratio X-ray absorption spectroscopy. 0 3 16 24 32 4C 48 ENBCY ABOVE TIE K SXZ W Fig. 1. X-ray absorption spectra near the Ca K edge of calcium adenosine triphosphate, calcium hydrogen phosphate, calcium acetate and calcium carbonate- In fig- 1 is reported the Ca K absorption spectra of the calcium adenosine triphosphate (CaATP), calcium acetate, calcium hydrogen phosphate (CaHP04) and calcium carbonate (CaCOs). The absorption coefficient has been calculated from transmission measurements using the formula a = —(l{d) In r, where d is the thickness of the sample. A dear similarity is observed between the CaATP spectrum and the CaHP04 spectrum in contrast with the different features observed in the Ca acetate and carbonate spectra- The CaC03 spectrum shows a strong peak D about 20 eV above the first peak AI - This spectrum is in good agreement with the measure- ments of Sugiura et al. [15]. This feature is charac- teristic of CaC03 which has a crystal structure which belongs to the D^a space group and where the Ca is bound to the €03 radicals- In fig. 2 is plotted the first derivative of the absorption spectrum (solid line) and the second derivative (dashed line) calculated from the transmission data using a PDP/11 computer. These spectra strongly show the power of synchrotron radiation to obtain high resolution spectra. The zero of energy is put at the first maximum A of the first derivative spectrum of CaATP- The absolute energy of the derivative peak B ofCaCOs is 4042.6 eV following ref. [15], therefore the energy of peak A of CaATP is 4038.4 eV. For comparison the K edge of calcium metal is at 4038.1 eV [15]. A strong similarity between the spectrum of CaHP04 and CaATP is observed- Peak A is split in Ca acetate and Ca carbonate as well as the peak C. A chemical shift of the structures towards higher energy is found going from CaCOa to CaHPOa. The chemical shift due to Table 1 Features in fig. 2 CaATP CaHP04 Ca acetate CaCOs AB C 05.7 eV 10.7 eV 05.7 eV 9.5 eV -13 eV +2-3 eV 5.5 eV 9.8 eV -0.4 eV +1.1 eV 4.2 eV 9.4 eV 12.0 eV feature in fig. 1 C 13.4 eV 13.3 eV 11.5eV 10.9 eV 122 Volume 59, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 November 1978 0 2 4 S 8 » ENERGY ABOVE THE K EDGE feM Fig. 2. First derivative (solid line) and second derivative (dashed line) of the K absorption spectra ofCaATP complex and of several simple calcium compounds plotted in fig. 1. The arrows indicate the energy position of the main absorption peak C. the electronic charge state of the Ca ion is the same in CaATPandCaHP04. To understand the physical origin of structures A, B and C, the well known Z + 1 analogy [16] can be used. In fact the Z + 1 analogy can reveal the energy position of the excited states [12,17]. This idea assumes that for inner-shell excitations the one electron model is a good first approximation- The effect of the hole created by the photoabsorption process in the Is-shell can be simulated by adding one positive charge to the nuclear charge. The number of electrons in the valence orbitals should be increased by one. Therefore as far as the energetics of the final excited molecular orbitals is concerned the final states of an ion having atomic number Z can be taken as that of an ion with atomic number Z + I but having a fully occupied shell- Assuming that the first excited states are strongly localized on the absorbing atom (considering them as core excitons their radius can be smaller than the interatomic distance) so the atomic character of these excited states can be relevant. In this case the atomic spsctroscopic tables [18] of the element (Z + 1) can be used to calculate the final state energies of the fully relaxed ion. We have compared the Ca2"1' excited states lsl2sl2p63s23p6n'l' with the excited states of Sc2"*" Is^s^p^s^p6/^'. The atomic tables [18] for the free Sc^"1' ion give a 3.2 eV separation of the 3d—4s orbitals and a 4-5 eV separation of the 4s—4p orbitals. Following the Z + 1 analogy we assign the weak peak A in fig. 1 and fig- 2 at the X-ray absorp- tion threshold to the forbidden Is ->- 3d transition. The shoulder B on the rapidly rising absorption curve is assigned to the Is ->- 4s transition and the strong peak C to the allowed Is -> 4p transition. The energy separation 5.8 eV between A and B and the 4.9 eV separation between C and B are larger than the spectroscopie values of the Z + 1 free ion- This fact indicates that, also if the Z + 1 analogy is in qualita- tive agreement with the data, the molecular character of the excited states cannot be disregarded. The 1.5 eV splitting of peak A is observed in CaC03 and a similar 3.6 eV splitting is present also in calcium acetate. In the CaC03 spectrum also the peak C is 2.6 eV split. We assign this effect to the splitting of the d-like and p-like levels in the molecular field of CaC03. An upper limit for the continuum threshold energy can be estimated in the CaC03 spectrum. Since the final state energy of the core transition A cannot be degenerate with the occupied valence states, the binding energy of this discrete state (i.e. the energy separation between its energy and the con- duction band threshold) cannot be higher than the optical band gap between the valence and the con- duction band 9 ± 0.5 eV [19] . Therefore the highest possible energy of the conduction band threshold is »s 9 eV above the peak A. Peak C should be degenerated with the continuum. However this peak which has a strong oscillator strength can be an inner-well resonance localized inside the electronega- tive potential barrier due to the oxygen ions [20] also if its energy is degenerated with the continuum. The close similarity between the CaATP and the CaHP04 spectra suggests that the calcium site in the two compounds is similar- In fact the almost identical spectra indicate the same charge state of the ion and similar site symmetry. The chemical-nature of the 123 Volume 59, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I November 1978 surrounding atoms also seems likely to be similar in the two compounds. This result supports the hypothe- sis that the Ca^"*" ion is bound to the oxygen atoms in the phosphate group (HPdO2" ofATP [5]. In conclusion we have measured, using synchrotron radiation, high resolution X-ray absorption spectra near the K edge ofCa in simple model compounds and ATP- The chemical applications of the K edge absorption spectroscopy to comparison of the local bonding with that of model compounds has been demonstrated in the relatively simple case ofCaATP complex. This experiment is preliminary to more interesting experiments for determining Ca site binding in proteins and other more complex bio- logical compounds. C 6 (1973) 1450. 124 1 free ion- This fact indicates that, also if the Z + 1 analogy is in qualita- tive agreement with the data, the molecular character of the excited states cannot be disregarded. The 1.5 eV splitting of peak A is observed in CaC03 and a similar 3.6 eV splitting is present also in calcium acetate. In the CaC03 spectrum also the peak C is 2.6 eV split. We assign this effect to the splitting of the d-like and p-like levels in the molecular field of CaC03. An upper limit for the continuum threshold energy can be estimated in the CaC03 spectrum. Since the final state energy of the core transition A cannot be degenerate with the occupied valence states, the binding energy of this discrete state (i.e. the energy separation between its energy and the con- duction band threshold) cannot be higher than the optical band gap between the valence and the con- duction band 9 ± 0.5 eV [19] . Therefore the highest possible energy of the conduction band threshold is »s 9 eV above the peak A. Peak C should be degenerated with the continuum. However this peak which has a strong oscillator strength can be an inner-well resonance localized inside the electronega- tive potential barrier due to the oxygen ions [20] also if its energy is degenerated with the continuum. The close similarity between the CaATP and the CaHP04 spectra suggests that the calcium site in the two compounds is similar- In fact the almost identical spectra indicate the same charge state of the ion and similar site symmetry. The chemical-nature of the 123 Volume 59, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I November 1978 surrounding atoms also seems likely to be similar in the two compounds. This result supports the hypothe- sis that the Ca^"*" ion is bound to the oxygen atoms in the phosphate group (HPdO2" ofATP [5]. In conclusion we have measured, using synchrotron radiation, high resolution X-ray absorption spectra near the K edge ofCa in simple model compounds and ATP- The chemical applications of the K edge absorption spectroscopy to comparison of the local bonding with that of model compounds has been demonstrated in the relatively simple case ofCaATP complex. This experiment is preliminary to more interesting experiments for determining Ca site binding in proteins and other more complex bio- logical compounds. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Using synchrotron radiation the X-ray Ca K-absorption edges have been measured with high resolution. The Ca binding site in the adenosine triphosphate (ATP) has been studied. The K edges of simple Ca model compounds CaHPO3, CaCO3, and Ca(C2H3O2)2 have been measured, for comparison with the K edge of CaATP. The calcium site in ATP is similar to Ca site in calcium hydrogen phosphate.
